title: Edward Waldegrave
text:
Sir Edward Waldegrave (c. 15161 September 1561) was an <a href="England">English</a> courtier and Catholic <a href="recusancy">recusant</a>.
Family.
Edward Waldegrave was the eldest son of John Waldegrave (died 1543) by Lora Rochester, daughter of Sir John Rochester of Essex, and sister of <a href="Robert%20Rochester">Sir Robert Rochester</a>. He was the grandson of Sir Edward Waldegrave of Bures, <a href="Suffolk">Suffolk</a>, and a descendant of <a href="Richard%20Waldegrave%20%28politician%29">Sir Richard Waldegrave</a>, <a href="List%20of%20Speakers%20of%20the%20House%20of%20Commons%20of%20England">Speaker of the House of Commons</a>.
Career.
In 1547 Waldegrave joined the household of <a href="Mary%20I%20of%20England">Princess Mary</a>, and was granted the <a href="manorialism">manor</a> and <a href="rectory">rectory</a> of <a href="West%20Haddon">West Haddon</a>, <a href="Northamptonshire">Northamptonshire</a>. He also bought the manor of Borley in Essex, and made that his home.
In 1551 he was imprisoned in the <a href="Tower%20of%20London">Tower of London</a> by <a href="Edward%20VI%20of%20England">King Edward VI</a> (with Rochester and <a href="Francis%20Englefield">Francis Englefield</a>), for refusing to carry out the <a href="Privy%20Council%20of%20the%20United%20Kingdom">Privy Council</a>'s ban on Mary having <a href="mass%20%28liturgy%29">mass</a> said in her house of <a href="Copt%20Hall">Copt Hall</a>, near <a href="Epping%2C%20Essex">Epping</a>, <a href="Essex">Essex</a>. He was released a year later and on Mary's accession in 1553 he was knighted, admitted to the Privy Council, granted the manors of <a href="Navestock">Navestock</a>, Essex, and <a href="Chewton%20Mendip">Chewton</a>, Somerset, and appointed <a href="Master%20of%20the%20Great%20Wardrobe">Master of the Great Wardrobe</a>.
Waldegrave was then elected to the <a href="Parliament%20of%20England">Parliament of England</a> for <a href="Wiltshire%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Wiltshire</a> in October 1553, twice for <a href="Somerset%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Somerset</a> in 1554 and lastly for <a href="Essex%20%28UK%20Parliament%20constituency%29">Essex</a> in 1558. He succeeded Rochester as <a href="Chancellor%20of%20the%20Duchy%20of%20Lancaster">Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster</a> in 1554 and was granted the manor of <a href="Cobham%2C%20Kent">Cobham, Kent</a>. However, after Mary's death a year later, he was dismissed from all his posts and committed to the Tower again, by <a href="Elizabeth%20I%20of%20England">Queen Elizabeth</a>, for allowing mass to be celebrated in his house.
Waldegrave died in the Tower in 1561. His grandson was <a href="Sir%20Edward%20Waldegrave%2C%201st%20Baronet">Sir Edward Waldegrave, 1st Baronet</a>.
As Master of the Wardrobe, Waldegrave managed the financial account of the funeral of <a href="Edward%20VI%20of%20England">Edward VI</a>. Waldegrave had a budget of £1300 and a consignment of rich fabrics delivered from the queen's stock by <a href="Ralph%20Sadler">Ralph Sadler</a>.
Marriage and issue.
Waldegrave married Frances Neville, a daughter of the executed <a href="Edward%20Neville">Sir Edward Neville</a>, by whom he had five children.
